properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An area of freezing rain is forecast to move into northern Alberta from B.C. beginning this evening. The amount of freezing rain will vary depending on location but up to 1 mm of accretion is possible for areas that see prolonged periods of freezing rain tonight. The freezing rain will end overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T11:59:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T21:28:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3644908110.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First accumulating snowfall of the season expected for many areas. Total snowfall: near 5 cm, with higher amounts over elevated terrain. Locations: central, western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: late tonight through Tuesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin over western Newfoundland near midnight tonight and will spread into central and northern parts of the island by early Tuesday morning. The snow will change to rain over most areas by midday on Tuesday, but may persist through Tuesday afternoon and evening over parts of the Northern and Baie Verte Peninsulas, especially over higher terrain. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-27T10:18:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T18:19:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1690113772.2020

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By Town Of Lashburn
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for Town of Lashburn due to depressurization caused by line maintenance. This advisory applies to residents and users located on 2nd Street East between Ross Avenue and Cressman Avenue effective October 26, 2020.
Expires: 2020-10-30T17:00:00-06:00

Area: Town of Lashburn on 2nd Street East between Ross Avenue and Cressman Avenue
properties.Author: SK Lashburn

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds, with wind gusts approaching 90 km/h, are expected to continue tonight over the region. Winds are forecast to diminish Tuesday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T13:22:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T21:23:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3063112636.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Storm-total snowfall amounts from 15 to 25 cm are expected by midday. A frontal system crossing the Yukon and norther BC will continue give snow to the region this morning. Snow is expected to ease for most areas later this morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T06:53:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T14:54:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1042805906.2020
Area: Teslin, Cassiar Mountains, Watson Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow will continue to fall over the region tonight and is expected to taper off during the day on Tuesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T13:21:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T21:22:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3653172282.2020
Area: Ft. Simpson Region including Jean Marie River, Wrigley Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Conditions are favourable for the development of snow squalls which may impact Coral Harbour beginning overnight and through Tuesday. If snow squalls develop, 15 to 25 cm of heavy, rapidly accumulating snow is possible by Tuesday evening. Conditions become less favourable for snow squall development overnight on Tuesday. Please stay alert to updated bulletins, as the development of snow squalls will be monitored. If snow squalls develop, this snow squall watch will be upgraded to a snow squall warning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T11:23:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T19:24:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2800863263.2020
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A frontal system will move across the interior tonight through Tuesday. Light snow associated with the system this evening will become heavier overnight. The snow is expected to ease late Tuesday afternoon with total accumulations up to 15 cm possible. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T15:53:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T23:54:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0682941599.2020
Area: Yellowhead Highway – Tête Jaune Cache to the Alberta Border
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A front over the Alaska Panhandle will move onto the north coast of B.C. early this evening and reach the central coast overnight. The front will then stall on Tuesday and remain over the area. Heavy rain is expected to begin tonight and continue into Tuesday night. Rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm over inland areas and near 100 mm over coastal areas are forecast by midnight Tuesday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T15:24:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T23:25:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3984890508.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections, Central Coast - inland sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Snow continues to fall over the central Yukon as a slow moving winter storm crosses the region. 10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen today, with additional snowfall amounts ranging from 2 to 5 cm possible tonight. Snow is expected to ease through the night as the system weakens and exits the region. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T10:59:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T22:41:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1866634374.2020
Area: Dawson, Mayo
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A front over the Alaska Panhandle will move onto the north coast of B.C. early this evening and reach the central coast overnight. As the front passes, about 50 mm of heavy rain is expected for coastal areas before easing overnight. The rain combined with melting snow at higher elevations may contribute to increased risk of localised flooding or washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T13:54:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T23:24:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2000069094.2020
Area: North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong, gusty winds upwards of 80 km/h gusting to 100 are expected into the later half of the evening. Coupled with falling snow, blizzard conditions will continue. Conditions are expected to improve later this evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T14:37:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-26T22:38:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0608129874.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A frontal system moving into the southwest Yukon will spread additional snow from the southwestern Yukon to the central Yukon today. Snow will ease later this morning in the southwest as the system crosses the area but persist until this evening elsewhere. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall amounts from 15 to 25 cm are expected through today. A frontal system, moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska is spreading significant snowfall amounts from central BC to the southern Yukon. The snow is expected to ease for most areas this afternoon as the front moves eastward. Another frontal system is expected to bring more snow to the Yellowhead region tonight through Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First significant early season snowfall tonight. Locations: northern New Brunswick. Time span: this afternoon and into early Tuesday morning. Remarks: A shot of snow already fell for parts of central and northern New Brunswick early this afternoon. More snow is again moving over northern New Brunswick this afternoon and will changeover to rain tonight over most regions before ending Tuesday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected however, more accumulation is likely over higher terrain where temperatures will be colder. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-27T10:50:54-00:00
